docs.lead_paragraph: CITY of Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert, Brahms, sundry Strausses, Mahler, Schoenberg, Berg and Webern. City of Freud, Adler and Reich. A burnished nostalgia crosses paths with a studied forgetfulness, and myth lurks at every turn. When the Vienna Philharmonic performed Beethoven's Ninth Symphony recently in the quarry of a former Nazi concentration camp in Mauthausen, Austria, 120 miles to the west, it knowingly waded into deep waters of memory and repression, meaning and association, hope and delusion. And all of that is to reckon without the late-breaking international fracas over Jorg Haider and the Freedom Party, as the orchestra did through most of its four years of planning.

headline.main: Wading Into Depths of Memory and Repression

docs.abstract: Vienna Philharmonic, performing Beethoven's Ninth Symphony in quarry of former concentration camp in Mauthausen, Austria, in tribute to victims of Nazis, brings home Austria's past to younger generation and raises anew questions about the uses and misuses of music; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THANDIE NEWTON, the British actress who will be seen on screen under John Woo's direction inflaming the passions of three men with chiseled jaws (including Tom Cruise) when ''M:i-2,'' the ''Mission: Impossible'' sequel, opens on Wednesday, does not so much enter the cafe of the Four Seasons Hotel here as materialize. One minute the circular foyer is empty. The next, it contains a slight, straight-haired young woman, bare-legged below a slim black skirt, wearing red flip-flops and no apparent makeup. It's a dancer's entrance more than an actress's, both in its reliance on the eloquence of line and carriage and in its air of waiting for the music to begin. And though at 11 a.m. on a foggy May morning the cafe is nearly deserted, and the young woman unassumingly pretty and visibly pregnant, those heads that are present turn. It is suddenly no longer possible to be unaware of the difference between ''at rest'' and ''in motion.'' That the 27-year-old Ms. Newton, who intended to be a dancer and trained intensively from ages 11 to 16, commands a body language that rivals in precision her Cambridge-educated English (she took her degree in anthropology) will surprise no one who saw her in Bernardo Bertolucci's ''Besieged'' (1998). As an African medical student supporting her studies in Rome by housecleaning for an expatriate British pianist (David Thewlis), Ms. Newton conveyed, in a single slow twist of her fingers across her lips, as much fascination with an alien culture, as much awareness of the temptations of both losing and affirming oneself through desire, as the passionate declarations of Mr. Thewlis's character.

headline.main: Poised for a Liberating Dance With Stardom

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I had my first child at age 36 and was pleased with my ultrasounds and all of the blood tests results. I opted to skip the amniocentesis. Now, at age 39 and pregnant with my second, I am delighted with the opportunity to participate in the clinical trial for the ultrasound and blood test done in the first trimester. Even though the amniocentesis is recommended based upon my age, I am choosing to take every noninvasive test available.
docs.abstract: Letter from Amy Saland on prenatal testing she has chosen to have, and tests she will not have, during her pregnancy (May 9 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Soon, the human genome will be completely mapped allowing doctors to detect, treat and prevent disease on a level unimaginable a few decades ago. But while genetic screening tests are remarkable diagnostic tools, they are not without potential harm to those who happen to carry a deleterious trait. As a physician who routinely orders such tests, I thought I long understood this dynamic. But I needed my wife, Kate, for a more definitive lesson. When Kate told me she was pregnant with our first child I was, of course, elated. Soon enough, I began to worry about the possibility of a less than perfectly healthy baby. Most expectant parents nervously ponder this issue, but my work as a pediatrician creates an especially skewed vision: many of the children who inhabit my world are among that tiny minority with the most serious and often the rarest illnesses. In a strange sense, when abnormality and disease dominate your view, it becomes ''normal.''

headline.main: One Side Effect of Genetic Testing: Fear

docs.abstract: Dr Howard Markel article on his apprehension as expectant father when his pregnant wife tests positive for rare genetic disease; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: If doctors had been able to give me the information about my baby prenatally that they gave me when my son was 6 months old, in 1995, I would have seriously considered abortion (''Advances, and Angst, in a New Era of Ultrasound,'' May 9). To put a little baby through the ''life'' that the doctors described seemed unthinkable. My son has the most severe form of spinal muscular atrophy, a common genetic cause of death in young children. Then, technology was not available to diagnose it prenatally.
docs.abstract: Letter from Anne Teare Freedman letter on May 9 article on advances in prenatal testing, which were not available when she was pregnant with severely handicapped baby

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''As the Tiniest Babies Grow, So Can Their Problems'' (front page, May 8) makes some assumptions that potentially support a disturbing viewpoint. It is not disabilities alone that ''can keep children from living independently, or ever having a social life or being able to function in society,'' as you quote a specialist as saying, but the social stigma and isolation a person with a disability faces in our society.
docs.abstract: Letter from Carl Herr says May 8 article on later problems of most premature babies should have addressed social stigma and isolation that person with disability faces in this society
